content.description:
Start the same as for

Ghost to Me

, but move your right hand up first, and veer slightly to the left.

Start on two incut rails/crimps, and make a hard deadpoint move up and right.  After you stick the hard first move, there are a few different possibilities for moving up and left to the slopey ledge/jug. After the slopey ledge/jug, hold it together for the lip.

If you want the beta spray, watch Christian's video.
content.protection: Two boulder pads are nice - one for flat ground, another blocking the boulder directly behind the landing.
content.location: Approaching from the trail and looking at the boulder, this is the furthest line on the right hand side (west side) of the boulder. The line in the middle is a V7+.

content.description: Start with your right hand on a thin, slanted crimp and your left hand on an even worse, horizontal crimp. Tic tac your way straight up and left on more small edges.
content.location: Look for chalked up crimps on the left side of the face.

content.description: Start matched on a flat edge in the center of the face, directly in front of a small boulder in the pit. Make a big, left hand move to a half-pad crimp, and continue up and slightly right on crimps.

Start standing, perched on the small boulder at the base with your left hand on a small hidden pocket (just left of the arete) at around 5-6 feet and your right hand on a good flat edge at 8 feet. A good hold above leads to a committing crux sequence gaining the lip and avoiding dabbing on a boulder to the left.

This has really good rock quality and movement, but the boulder at left is annoying and the landing could be better. Still, it is a worthwhile line and a good moderate option for those looking to climb on this wall.

I also did this from a slightly lower start with my left hand in the same place, but my right in a small pocket 5 feet right of the arete (at the same level). It felt pretty much the same difficulty, but I liked the above start better.
content.protection: Three or four pads and a spotter would be ideal.
content.location: This climb is located on the left arete when looking at the boulder.
